sec.title: Background:
sec.p: The TB Mukt Gram Panchayat program was launched by the National Health Mission in Rajasthan on August 15, 2022 to engage Panchayati Raj Institutions at the grass-root level to strengthen the fight against tuberculosis (TB). This study was conducted to assess the progress and achievements of this program in Rajasthan.

sec.title: Methodology:
sec.p: The methodology involved the collaborative development of assessment criteria by expert stakeholders to assess the TB-free status of Gram Panchayats (GPs)/Wards (WAs) in Rajasthan. Two stages were conducted: shortlisting based on specific criteria, including active case finding and treatment linkage, and final assessment using a standardized questionnaire. Indicators assessed included program delivery, active case finding, community awareness, community support, district capacity, and TB burden, each with defined qualifying criteria and achievement scores, yielding final scores for each GP.

sec.title: Results:
sec.p: In the context of the GP/WA TB-Free Declaration Status, the results depict a mix of statuses, including “Progress toward TB-free status” and “Achieved TB-free status.” Out of 51 GPs/WAs, 29 achieved TB-free status, 13 were in progress toward TB-free status, and the rest were not qualified, having incomplete coverage.

sec.title: Conclusion:
sec.p: This study highlights the progress in Rajasthan’s TB Mukt Gram Panchayat program and exemplifies stakeholder collaboration across sectors in developing a verification framework for TB Mukt Gram Panchayat claims. Moreover, this novel assessment framework offers a valuable tool for other states to monitor their progress toward TB elimination.

sec.title: INTRODUCTION
sec.p: Tuberculosis (TB) remains a significant public health challenge in India, and various initiatives have been undertaken to combat this infectious disease.[1] One such initiative is the “TB Mukt Gram Panchayat” program launched by the National Health Mission in Rajasthan on August 15, 2022.[23] This program aims to engage Panchayati Raj Institutions (PRIs) at the grass-root level to strengthen the fight against TB.[4]

This program was intended to sensitize TB Champions at the Panchayat level and involve local Panchayat leaders in awareness activities.[3] The program specifically aimed to create awareness about TB, promote early diagnosis and treatment, support TB patients and their families, and engage diverse stakeholders, including healthcare workers, teachers, religious groups, and voluntary organizations.[35] It also involves public health actions such as Tuberculosis Preventive Treatment (TPT) for contacts, bank seeding for Nikshay Poshan Yojana, UDST, Contact tracing, HIV, and Blood sugar testing.[35]

Under this campaign, 1412 Gram Panchayats (GPs)/Wards (WAs) across the state were covered, with the goal of achieving PRI ownership and fostering a societal movement toward TB elimination. Five GPs/WAs were selected in each TB unit for achieving the “TB-free Gram Panchayat”, and a Patient Support Group (PSG) of 10 to 12 individuals was formed (including Sarpanch, Deputy Sarpanch, Panchayat Secretary, Medical Officers, TB champions, CHOs, ANMs, ASHA, Anganwadi workers, government teachers, spiritual corporations, voluntary corporations, and other contributors).[3] TB champions were identified in each Panchayat, and consciousness activities were organized by them in the presence of nearby Panchayat leaders. NiKshay Gram Sabha was also organized on days of countrywide significance, like August 15, 2022 (Independence Day) and January 26, 2023 (Republic Day), in collaboration with the Panchayati Raj Department.[3] Motivational TB Pledge marketing campaign was organized on Republic Day. The campaign’s three key components include active case finding, community awareness, and community support.[3]

With the aim to provide valuable insights that can further strengthen the program’s effectiveness, contributing to the broader objective of eliminating TB in Rajasthan by 2025, this study was conducted to assess the progress and achievements of the “TB Mukt Gram Panchayat” program in Rajasthan.

sec.p: Two-stage assessment criteria were collaboratively developed by expert stakeholders from the State TB cell, WHO TB Consultant network, State TB Training and Demonstration Centre (STDC) Ajmer, State Technical Support Unit (STSU), AIIMS Jodhpur, and the Medical and Health Department of Rajasthan to evaluate the TB-free status of GPs/WAs. sec.p: Stage 2: Final assessment of shortlisted GPs
GPs, shortlisted in Stage 1, underwent a final assessment using a standardized questionnaire-based identified indicator. The following were the indicators with respective components:

list-item.p: Program Delivery: It encompassed the awareness of GP/WA Support Group members about the campaign and their roles; the execution of planned GP/WA Support Group meetings; and management and follow-up activities for current TB patients, including those in the private sector, along with interventions for HIV/DM, U-DST, and contact tracing. Additionally, the treatment success rate among patients completing treatment and the proportion of eligible individuals initiating preventive therapy was also considered.

Active case finding: This component involved assessment of the active case finding (ACF) teams being proficiently trained in recognizing vulnerable groups of the population, symptoms of TB, proper sputum collection, and referral processes; proportion of identified vulnerable populations; proportion of TB presumptive patients referred for testing with Ni-kshay ID; and the prompt initiation of treatment for current TB patients within 7 days of diagnosis. Furthermore, the proportion of notified TB patients placed on the 99 DOTS (ICT-supported adherence system) was also considered to ensure comprehensive and technology-enhanced care for better treatment outcomes.

Community Awareness: This indicator was pivotal with several key components. Tracking the number of Gram Sabha meetings held and measuring the proportion of stakeholders made aware of the TB Mukt GP WA campaign were considered to reflect the outreach and inclusivity of the awareness efforts. Additionally, the proportion of activities led by TB champions, sites displaying IEC messages, and the number of participants taking the TB Pledge were included to assess community commitment and involvement in the campaign.

Community Support: This indicator includes several critical components. First, it includes tracking the number of TB patients connected with Ni-kshay Mitr and receiving nutritional support in the GP/WA. The indicator also measured the proportion of TB patients or survivors benefiting from home visits and the experiences of TB patients in terms of workplace or neighborhood stigma, abuse, or violence. Furthermore, the overall quality of care and frequent follow-up counseling for both TB patients and their families was assessed.

District Capacity Assessment: This indicator involved a multifaceted evaluation of key components. First, the indicator includes assessing the number of monthly meetings held by the District Tuberculosis Officer (DTO), where the TB Mukt GP WA Campaign Progress was discussed. Additionally, the evaluation encompasses the number of District Health Society (DHS) meetings, where TB Mukt GP WA Progress was deliberated. The assessment extends to the Selection of GP WA, involving profiling through the GP WA Directory, Demographic Profile, Vulnerable population listing, and Facility Mapping for ACF. It also evaluated the formation and sensitization of GP WA Support Groups and ACF Teams. The linkage of GP WA-wise mapped facilities with nearby DMC/NAAT sites, logistic arrangements, identification and sensitization of TB Champions and Community Volunteers, development of Supportive Supervision and Monitoring Visit plans, registration of Ni-kshay Mitr for nutritional support, and the budget allocation for TB Mukt GP WA Campaign activities were integral components of this comprehensive assessment.

TB burden: The indicators included the TB incidence rate (44 cases per lakh population), reflecting the number of new TB cases reported annually. The TB prevalence rate (65 cases per lakh population) indicates the total number of individuals living with TB in the state. Additionally, the TB mortality rate (3 deaths per lakh population), providing insights into the number of TB-related fatalities, was also considered.

sec.p: The Qualifying Criteria and Achievement Score were defined for each indicator, and the final score for each GP was based on the percentage achievement of the maximum score for each indicator (refer to Table 2).

sec.title: RESULTS
sec.p: In the initial phase, 51 GPs/WAs out of 1415 were selected for the final field assessment, considering the following key indicators:

list-item.p: Program delivery: The performance of various GPs, including Panchayats and WAs, was extensively analyzed, focusing on their program delivery achievements and scores (scores out of 15 and qualifying criteria > 50%). Remarkably, all Panchayats/WAs demonstrated exemplary proficiency in program delivery, attaining scores higher than 50%. The aggregate performance exhibited a mean score of 13.3 ± 1.6, with a majority achieving scores of more than 80%. This highlights a robust dedication to the effective implementation of TB control programs within the respective communities.

Active Case Finding: With a maximum achievable score of 15 and a qualifying criterion set at > 50%, the comprehensive analysis of the active case finding component showcased that all GP/WA demonstrated considerable proficiency, achieving scores higher than 60%. The results indicate a mean score of 13.2 ± 1.2. This remarkable consistency highlights the program’s efficacy and success in identifying and addressing TB cases within the communities. The high levels of achievement across the board, with a majority surpassing 80%, reflect a robust commitment to active case finding and underscore the program’s positive impact on TB control initiatives in the region.

Community Awareness: The analysis of the community awareness component reveals significant progress. With a maximum achievable score of 15 and a qualifying criterion set at > 40%, the shortlisted GP demonstrated commendable performance. The achieved scores ranged from 47% to a perfect 100%, with a mean score of 11.7 ± 2.4. Remarkably, all GPs surpassed the qualifying criterion, indicating a commitment to raising community awareness about TB. Though around 12 GP/WA scored less than ten instances with perfect scores or scores exceeding 80%, this highlights the effectiveness of the program in disseminating information and fostering understanding within the communities. The results highlight the program’s success in enhancing awareness levels and promoting proactive community engagement in the fight against TB in the region.

Community Support: Assessment of the community support component demonstrates a diverse range of achievements. With a maximum achievable score of 15 and a qualifying criterion set at > 40%, GP/WA displayed a commitment to community support initiatives with a mean score of 11 ± 2.5. This score displayed the program’s impact on fostering community support for TB control. Instances achieving perfect scores or exceeding 80% highlighted success in garnering community backing. However, around five GPs scored 47%, which showed scope of improvement in securing community support. Figure 1 shows the box and whisker plot for the process indicators.

list-item.p: District Capacity: In assessing the district capacity, with a maximum achievable score of 10 and a qualifying criterion set at > 40%, the results showed a consistency in achieving high scores (mean = 8.1 ± 1), with the majority of districts attaining 70% and above. Impressively, several districts demonstrated good performance, consistently achieving a score of 90%. This signifies a robust capacity in these districts to effectively implement and sustain the TB control program. Figure 2: Box and whisker plot for the same.

list-item.p: TB Incidence, Prevalence, and Mortality: A thorough examination of TB incidence, prevalence, and mortality revealed that 33 GPs/WAs met the qualifying criterion for a TB incidence rate of 44 cases per lakh, 48 GPs met the qualifying criterion for a TB prevalence rate, and 49 GPs met the qualifying criterion for a TB mortality rate of 3 cases per lakh.

sec.p: In the context of the GP/WA TB-Free Declaration Status, the results depict a mix of statuses, including “Progress toward TB-free status” and “Achieved TB-free status.” Out of 51 GPs/WAs, 29 achieved TB-free status, 13 were in progress toward TB-free status, and the rest were not qualified, having incomplete coverage.

sec.title: DISCUSSION
sec.p: The findings from our study, which comprehensively assessed 1415 GPs/WAs across diverse districts, contribute valuable insights into the progress and achievements of the TB Mukt Gram Panchayat program in Rajasthan. Our study focused on various indicators, including program delivery, active case finding, community awareness, community support, district capacity, and TB incidence, prevalence, and mortality rates.

The remarkable performance of all shortlisted 51 GPs/WAs in program delivery, consistently achieving scores of 50% or higher, signifies a strong dedication to the effective implementation of TB control programs within the communities. This aligns with the study mentioned by Y Dholakia, 2022, which also highlighted the pivotal role of program delivery in successful TB control initiatives.[6]

Our analysis of the active case finding component reveals consistently high levels of achievement across all GP, with commendable mean scores of 13.2 and the majority exceeding 80%. These results align with the findings of Diepreye Ayabina et al.[7] and Nagaraja et al.,[8] emphasizing the efficacy of active case finding strategies in identifying and addressing TB cases within communities.

Progress in the community awareness component is significant, with perfect scores or scores exceeding 80%, accentuating the program’s effectiveness in disseminating information and fostering community understanding. Similar positive trajectories were observed in studies by Chávez-Rimache et al.[9] and Quraishi et al.,[10] highlighting the importance of community engagement in TB control efforts.

The assessment of community support reflects diverse achievements, with GP showcasing notable commitment. Instances of perfect scores or scores exceeding 80% highlight exceptional success in garnering community backing, consistent with the findings of Ritchie and Horton[11] and Dhinwa et al.[12] However, the identification of GPs with lower scores indicates areas where additional support and engagement may be warranted.

District capacity demonstrates consistently high performance, with the majority of districts achieving scores of 70% and above. The exemplary capacity of certain districts, consistently attaining a score of 90% and a perfect score of 100%, aligns with the findings of Salve and Porter, 2019,[13] showcasing robust capacity for the effective implementation and sustainability of TB control programs.

Evaluation of TB incidence, prevalence, and mortality rates demonstrates adherence to set standards positively impacts disease surveillance and control. Similar findings were reported by Afanvi[14] and Ehman et al.,[15] suggesting that maintaining standards for these rates contributes significantly to program success.

In summary, our study aligns with and contributes to existing literature, emphasizing the multifaceted nature of successful TB control programs and the importance of community engagement, strong program delivery, and robust district capacity. The challenges identified emphasize the need for targeted interventions and ongoing efforts to achieve TB-free status across all GPs/WAs. The GP/WA TB-Free Declaration Status results showcase a mix of achievements and challenges within different GPs/WAs. Several GPs/WAs have made noteworthy progress, achieving the coveted “TB-free status,” demonstrating their successful efforts in combating TB within their jurisdictions. The attainment of TB-free status by specific GPs/WAs highlights the sustained commitment and effective implementation of TB control measures. However, the presence of GPs marked as “Not Qualified” and “Progressing towards TB-free” indicates areas where further attention and intervention may be required. Understanding the reasons behind these designations can provide valuable insights into the challenges faced by certain GPs and WAs in reaching TB-free status.

sec.title: CONCLUSION
sec.p: In conclusion, this study assessed the TB Mukt Gram Panchayat program in Rajasthan, revealing progress across key indicators such as program delivery, active case finding, and community support. The findings highlight the effectiveness of community engagement and robust program delivery in combating TB. Importantly, the study also introduced a novel framework for assessing TB GPs, offering valuable insights for other states to monitor progress toward TB elimination. Moreover, it exemplifies stakeholder collaboration across sectors in developing a verification framework for TB Mukt Gram Panchayat claims. This framework provides a structured approach that can be adapted and utilized to strengthen TB elimination efforts nationwide.
